newsitem.title: SWEDEN: S-E-Banken, Nordbanken actively traded in Sweden.
newsitem.headline: S-E-Banken, Nordbanken actively traded in Sweden.

text.p: Swedish banks S-E-Banken and Nordbanken were actively traded on Monday with trade driven by new rumours of a merger between the two banks in the near future, brokers said.
S-E-Banken shares rose one crown to 73.50 crowns with over 1.77 million shares traded. Norbanken slipped 2.5 crowns to 231 crowns with 470,000 shares changing hands.
"It is looking more and more likely that there will be a merger between the banks and enough people in the market now believe that," said one broker.

Swedish daily newspaper Dagens Nyheter on Friday fuelled rumours in the market with an article speculating on a possible merger this week. Head staff at the bank had cancelled holiday plans, the daily said.
Finance newspaper Finanstidningen on Monday said high street bank Nordbanken, which is owned 59 percent by the Swedish state, could buy arch-rival S-E-Banken.
It said a purchase was being discussed by the two banks and an announcement could be made in coming week.
"All these rumours must have some truth in them but it is still difficult to say how the deal will look," said an analyst. "But there is a lot of speculation capital now tied up in this."
